body:
I see a similar problem when running a watchr autounit script (for continuous testing, see https://gist.github.com/287950). I've updated the github project to illustrate this and added some tests that are not process isolated for comparison.

The output of the autounit script is this:

```
PHPUnit 3.6.4 by Sebastian Bergmann.

..EE

Time: 1 second, Memory: 3.50Mb

There were 2 errors:

1) Acme\Tests\ProcessIsolationTest::testFirstProcess
RuntimeException: Usage: watchr [opts] path/to/script

/Users/wayne/pear/bin/phpunit:43

2) Acme\Tests\ProcessIsolationTest::testSecondProcess
RuntimeException: Usage: watchr [opts] path/to/script

/usr/bin/phpunit:44
```

I've tried to reproduce it and for me ant just hangs and does nothing until i kill it. I'll see if that fixes it too for me.

---

Yep. That fixes it too. Thanks a lot for the report and sorry for the BC break there!

We'll see how we can resolve this

@asartalo Any chance you can isolate that use case further still?

I've tried a simple ruby script

``` ruby
system("php -r 'var_dump($_SERVER);'")
```

But that yields the correct value ("/usr/bin/php") in `$_SERVER['_']`...
@edorian I'll write a quick ant task that calls PHP and see what the result of that is...

@dzuelke  

`$_SERVER['_'];` is pointing to `/usr/bin/ant` for me using something like:

``` xml
<target name="stuff">
     <exec executable="./foo">
        <arg line="--test hi ho" />
    </exec>
</target>
```

and foo being

``` php
    #!/usr/bin/php
    <?php

    var_dump($_SERVER['argv']);
    var_dump($_SERVER['_']);
```

gives me

```
 [exec] array(4) {
 [exec]   [0]=>
 [exec]   string(5) "./foo"
 [exec]   [1]=>
 [exec]   string(6) "--test"
 [exec]   [2]=>
 [exec]   string(2) "hi"
 [exec]   [3]=>
 [exec]   string(2) "ho"
 [exec] }
 [exec] string(12) "/usr/bin/ant"
```

I assume this is due to how ant handles the `<exec>` task. Looking for a way to fix / work around this

So, with a build file like

``` xml
<project>
  <exec executable="php" newenvironment="false" dir=".">
    <arg value="asdf.php" />
  </exec>
</project>
```

And `asdf.php` containing just

``` php
<?php var_dump($_SERVER['_']);
```

I get an undefined index notice, which means there is no `$_SERVER['_']`, which I suppose is bad news.

That seems unrelated to the issue @asartalo reported though, where that key for some obscure reason contains the path to the parent process.

The hack suggested there, calling `which php`, does not fix the issue, as that's exactly what #407 fixed (or tried to fix) - you cannot run tests using different PHP versions, for instance, as it'd always use the default PHP (unless you hack the `PATH`. which sucks).

Surely there must be a way to determine the PHP binary path? :(

And the issue I'm having seems to stem from  /usr/bin/ant starting with #!/bin/sh and `sh` is not a good value for the phpBinary :(

It fells rather hackish but how about checking the binary for 'strpos "php" ' and falling back on the default php version? It will not fix everything but it will restore the old behavior (for the most part, with some adaptions to the code at least)  and should still work out for your use case. 

If you have another Idea I'd gladly hear it. If not I'll prepare a patch

No, a `strpos()` on "php" is definitely not enough, it could occur anywhere in the executable path in the above situations (including the "phpunit" string or whatever).

`preg_match('^(.*?[\\\\/]php(-cli)?(\.exe)?\b)', ...)` might be better, or `preg_match(sprintf('^(.*?[%s/]php(-cli)?(\.exe)?\b)', preg_quote(DIRECTORY_SEPARATOR)), ...)` if you want to be 100% correct for the Windows case (slash can be used there too so it's always included).

I have heard of cases where "_" has two path parts or so in it though, so that'll fail, but using `\S+` rather than `.*?` isn't the way because spaces can be in path names, and I'm too tired to test this all right now :p

Hi everyone. 

Thanks for looking into this. Our usage only tests against one php version so the hack works for us but again, it's very unreliable.

I'm sorry I can't help much with narrowing down the examples because I'm not familiar with how watchr and ant launch/execute those commands. I'll see what I can find.

One possible workaround I'm thinking that is rather ugly is to pass the php bin path to phpunit directly as an argument. Like:

```
$ phpunit --php_bin=/usr/bin/php tests
```

Like I said: ugly. :(

P.S.

@dzuelke, I've upvoted the phph bug report. :)

> $ phpunit --php_bin=/usr/bin/php tests

phpunit does not have a `--php_bin` parameter, unfortunately.

`PHP_BINARY` has been implemented now according to http://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=54514, but we can't of course rely on that.

The ticket comment says there is `PHP_BINDIR`, but that's useless too:

```
localhost:~ dzuelke$ Code/oss/php/php-5.4.0RC1/sapi/cli/php -r 'var_dump(PHP_BINDIR);'
string(14) "/usr/local/bin"
```

However, `PHP_BINARY` gets the job done indeed:

```
localhost:PHP_5_4 dzuelke$ sapi/cli/php -r 'var_dump(PHP_BINARY);'
string(57) "/Users/dzuelke/Code/oss/php/branches/PHP_5_4/sapi/cli/php"
```

So my suggestion would be to always use `PHP_BINARY` if defined; if not, try to fall back to the regex I showed above. Not sure if we want to rely on `PHP_BINDIR`, it points to whatever was passed to `configure`, but I guess it's better than nothing.

Another case, this time with Phing: http://groups.google.com/group/agavi-users/browse_thread/thread/3d944d911ae9f66d

I'll try and prepare a patch tonight.
The patch works on my end.
